Package gw.api.web

  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    AbstractPageHelperImpl
    The empty implementation class for {@link PageHelper} interface. Extend this class when the sub class does not want to implement all methods in the interface.
    MBeanAttribute
    PageHelper
    Interface to be implemented by all UI helper classes for a PCF Location. For now, this is just a marker interface.
    RequestVar<T extends Object>
    The value assigned to an instance of this class is stored in the HttpRequest that is currently in scope, as tracked by the Guidewire platform. In some execution contexts, such as inside a batch process, a request is not available and accessing an instance of this class will result in an IllegalStateException. Use isRequestAvailable() to detect that situation. See below for a typical usage of a RequestVar. Access to the variable is encapsulated in the MyClass.MyRequestVar static property for ease of use. The RequestVar instance contains the key that is used to set and lookup the value of the variable in the HttpRequest. You cannot control which key is used, and so you must provide static access to the same RequestVar to access its value from different parts of the application. Note that although the property is static, that's only to hold the RequestVar and its key. Getting and setting the value will be done in the current HttpRequest, and so will be unique to each UI transaction. // Assign a value to the request variable // This can be done early in the request, such as in a PCF page MyClass.MyRequestVar = "hello" // Access the request variable // This could be done later, such as in rules or IPreUpdateHandler print( MyClass.MyRequestVar ) class MyClass { static var _varStoredInRequest = new RequestVar() static property get MyRequestVar() : String { if ( _varStoredInRequest.RequestAvailable ) { return _varStoredInRequest.get() } else { return null } } static property set MyRequestVar( value: String ) { if ( _varStoredInRequest.RequestAvailable ) { _varStoredInRequest.set( value ) } } }
    ScopedVar<T extends Object>
    ScopedVar.Scope  
    Scopes
    Provides maps scoped to various lifespans within a web-server's environment. The maps are not strongly typed. A typical usage of a request variable with Scopes. Access to the variable is encapsulated in the MyClass.MyRequestVar property for ease of use. // Assign a value to the request variable. // This can be done early in the request, such as in a PCF page MyClass.MyRequestVar = "hello" // Access the request variable // This could be done later, such as in rules or IPreUpdateHandler print( MyClass.MyRequestVar ) class MyClass { static var MY_REQUEST_VAR = "MyRequestVar" static property get MyRequestVar() : String { if ( Scopes.RequestAvailable ) { return Scopes.Request.get( MY_REQUEST_VAR ) as String } else { return null } } static property set MyRequestVar( value: String ) { if ( Scopes.RequestAvailable ) { Scopes.Request.put( MY_REQUEST_VAR, value ) } } }
    SessionVar<T extends Object>
    The value assigned to an instance of this class is stored in the HttpSession that is currently in scope, as tracked by the Guidewire platform. In some execution contexts, such as inside a batch process, a session is not available and accessing an instance of this class will result in an IllegalStateException. Use isRequestAvailable() to detect that situation (the HttpSession is obtained from the HttpRequest). Be careful when using SessionVar, since it can often lead to memory leaks or code executing in parallel cloberring each other's variable state. RequestVar is preferred for most usages of these two classes. See below for a typical usage of a SessionVar. Access to the variable is encapsulated in the MyClass.MySessionVar static property for ease of use. The SessionVar instance contains the key that is used to set and lookup the value of the variable in the HttpSession. You cannot control which key is used, and so you must provide static access to the same SessionVar to access its value from different parts of the application. Note that although the property is static, that's only to hold the SessionVar and its key. Getting and setting the value will be done in the current HttpSession, and so will be unique to each logged in user. // Assign a value to the session variable MyClass.MySessionVar = "hello" // Access the session variable print( MyClass.MySessionVar ) class MyClass { static var _varStoredInSession = new SessionVar() static property get MySessionVar() : String { if ( _varStoredInSession.RequestAvailable ) { return _varStoredInSession.get() } else { return null } } static property set MySessionVar( value: String ) { if ( _varStoredInSession.RequestAvailable ) { _varStoredInSession.set( value ) } } }
    WebFile  
    WebUtil
    Utility class for getting useful web information statically.
